We created Character Labs after helping a couple hundred startups build and launch new products.

I was thinking about some of the biggest takeaways from all‚Ä¶ | 38 comments on LinkedIn
data.text:
Don't Build a Flop! Test Your Idea Fast with MVP Development Imagine pouring your heart and soul into building a product, only to find out nobody wants it. Yikes! Unfortunately, that's the harsh reality for many startups. Ouch! 42% of startups fail because they build products nobody wants (Clutch survey). MVP (Minimum Viable Product) to the rescue! It's a simple version with core features that solve a problem. It's lean, mean, and built to learn. Why MVPs rock: ‚úÖGet real user feedback quickly. ‚úÖSpend less building something nobody wants. ‚úÖUser feedback helps you improve your product. Think of it like this: Before building a whole house, you wouldn't skip the blueprint stage, right? An MVP is your blueprint for a successful product. It allows you to test the foundation, make adjustments, and build something people value. MVP = Launch faster, learn faster, win faster. P.S-Launch your Minimum Viable Product (MVP) in just 4 weeks.

Picture this: You're competing with a dozen other startups. All have a strong idea and limited budget. How do you stand out? By bringing an MVP to market ASAP. Here's the secret no one tells you: The Pilot Plant Production model works best. You can test products and processes on a small-scale and validate before scaling. Iterative development allows for improvement and saves you time and money in the long run. No need to finance extra teams, capital, or resources. Just a small team and a willingness to course-correct along the way. Think small but go big. Aim for speed to market, and watch the rest follow suit.

Market looking for a product is key to early success of tech startups. Also, as important, Founders must know and have access to end users of their products early on in the product/service development cycle. Founders need to get customers involved in collaborative product and process development early on. The sooner you have a customer evaluate your product and provide feedback the higher the chances of success. Next make sure the niche you are in is a growing profitable niche or at least a stable one.

The Startup Sprint: Accelerating Success Leading a hardware startup? Every second counts. Avoid the drag of traditional design firms' slow research processes. Your product is a potential market disruptor. So choose teams who value speed without compromising quality. Your product should dazzle in function and form. So partner with experts in trends and tech for a product that shines. An adaptable, innovative team is key as launch day nears, turning challenges into refinements for a standout market entry. In the hardware startup race, strategic choices lead to success. Opt to work with people that understand the need for speed and thoroughness. It‚Äôs not JUST about launching first but launching the best. #SpeedToInnovation #DesignForStartups #Hardware

üöÄ "Hypotheses: What Supposed to Be True for Your Product or Startup Success?" In Startups and Products, it all revolves around identifying the Problem. If you've effectively articulated Problem you're aiming to solve, you're likely ahead of 80% of your competitors or other startups. Furthermore, the typical Pitch Deck structure might make one believe that it's enough just to define the Problem, come up with a Solution, quickly code something, and voil√† ‚Äì "Unique Insight." However, the reality is that there are numerous potential pitfalls, even if you've pinpointed a Problem: üö´ Problems that nobody wants to solve, üè¢ Problems that a specific startup or company can't solve, üí∞ Problems that don't have the potential to generate significant revenue. Do you agree? ü§î Share your thoughts! If you're interested in diving deeper, join our full webinar - sign up through the link below. üîó https://lnkd.in/eCuiF-i7 #ProductDevelopment #Prototype #MVP #DigitalProducts #Innovations #startupsuccess #productstrategy"

One week could change everything about your startup dream, but only if you apply to the Startup Battlefield 200 by June 17 at 11:59 p.m. PDT. Win $100,000 & Showcase At Disrupt 2024 San Francisco, October 28-30 Application: Visit Michael J Schick's profile below for the application link: https://lnkd.in/g_46ffuk Psst. Canadian Startups are ELIGIBLE. Behold the SB 200 benefits at TechCrunch Disrupt 2024 1. Along with the door-opening cachet associated with the TechCrunch seal of approval, all SB 200 companies receive these perks, benefits and opportunities. 2. Full access to Disrupt: SB 200 founders attend Disrupt for free and receive four additional passes and VIP access to all the presentations, breakouts and roundtables. 3. Free exhibition space for the entire show: The SB 200 will be the only early-stage startups allowed to exhibit at Disrupt. 4. Investor interest and media exposure: You can bet investors hunting for future unicorns and journalists looking for the next big story will beeline it for the exhibition floor to meet and greet the SB 200 founders. 5. Workshops and pitch training: SB 200 founders will be invited to exclusive workshops and masterclasses in the weeks running up to Disrupt. They‚Äôll also receive special pitch training from TechCrunch staff. 6. Flash-pitch to an audience of investors and TC editors: That training will come in handy when you step onto the Pitch Showcase Stage. You‚Äôll receive invaluable feedback, and you might find your way into an investor‚Äôs portfolio. 7. A shot at $100,000: TechCrunch editors will select 20 startups from the SB 200 to be Startup Battlefield finalists. Founders from those 20 companies will receive private pitch coaching, be featured in an article on TechCrunch and pitch live onstage in front of the entire Disrupt audience. The ultimate winner takes home the $100,000 equity-free prize.

In startups, rules are scarce but there‚Äôs one rule I always see broken. So many founders design for themselves, not their users. Your product may be innovative, but if it doesn't meet user needs, it'll struggle to gain traction. It's easy for founders, who are so deep in their product (and their industry tbh), to design based on their own understanding and assumptions. The thing is, users might not share the same knowledge, expertise, or perspective as you. Have a clear user in mind. Design based on assumptions. BUT test early and be prepared to find out you‚Äôve got it all wrong.
